description: It is safe to immunise a child who has a minor illness or a disability or is malnourished.
title: It is safe to immunise a child who has a minor illness or a disability or is malnourished
content:
- Many parents do not take a child to be immunised because the child
   has a fever, cough, cold, diarrhoea or some other illness. However,
   it is safe to immunise a child who has a minor illness.

 - It is also safe to immunise a child who has a disability or is
   malnourished.

 - If a child is HIV-positive or suspected to be HIV-positive, a trained
   health worker should be consulted about which vaccines to give the
   child.

 - After an injection, the child may cry or develop a fever, a minor
   rash or a small sore. This is normal and shows that the vaccine is
   working. Children under 6 months of age should breastfeed frequently;
   older children should be given plenty of liquids and foods. If the
   child develops a high fever (over 38 degrees Celsius) the child
   should be taken to a trained health worker or health centre.

 - Measles can be extremely dangerous for malnourished children, so they
   should be immunised against measles, especially if the malnutrition
   is severe.
